Elections for all other undergraduate offices were held last
week, but the balloting for the
office of SC president was voided
by the committee counting the
ballots when it was learned that
the incumbent president, Bob Peinado, had violated one of the rules
established by the Council to govern counting procedure.
The violated rule stated that no
ballots were to be counted prior
to 2 p.m. Thursday, the second day
of voting. Peinado, however,
counted Wednesday night a week
ago the results of the first day's
balloting.
The committee decided that the
violation of the election regulation necessitated the revote on
the grounds that, although it was
"highly probable" that the election was not influenced by the
premature vote - counting, "the
Council can control the moral considerations involved in an election
only by regulations set up previously to govern that election and
by the subsequent upholding of
those regulations." Sanford Cohen,
Herbert Belgrad, Porter Claxton,
Howard Waskow, and Peinado
comprised the committee.
Peinado last week explained his
action with "A law of the Council
was broken by my counting the
votes (with my roommate) ahead
of the prescribed time. Before
counting the votes I did consider
the ruling of the Council, but I
felt that I was not doing wrong
because I knew that neither I nor

Lew Sank has won the revote for the student Council
presidency, polling 281 votes.
Trailing him were Sam
Wright with 262 votes and Bob
Mitgang with 51 votes.
Sank stated, shortly after
his election, "I'd like to thank
the people who have supported
me and now I will endeavor to
carry out .the re-organization
of the Student Council so that
it will fulfill its purpose on
this campus. The first order of
business of the Student Council will be to pass a workable
constitution."
Herb Butler was named
chairman of Orientation Week
in a special session of the Student Council yesterday.

"Since this is the high mark of
our Spring Concert season, we are
indeed looking forward to giving
our best performance of the year,"
said Glee Club President Mayer
Liebman concerning the Club's
69th annual Home Concert to be
held tomorrow night at 8:30 p.m.
in Shriver Hall.
"Also, as admission is free for
undergraduates, we are hoping
the student body will support us
with their attendance. It should
be a delightful evening of good
music and entertainment," Liebman added. Tickets may be obtained from members of the Glee
Club.
Mr. Donald Regier, with Mr.
Richard Kapp as accompanist
will direct the seventy voice club
in numbers by Bach, Beethoven
and Tschasnokoff, and Mr. Kapp
will play a piano solo.
Music by Schubert, Mozart.
Gounod, and Rogers and Hammerstein will be featured in the second part of the concert.

The Dormitory Student Representative Council Constitution is
nearly ready for presentation to
the dorm students, according to
Constitution Chairman Don Gal/agher.
The constitution has been approved by Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer,
dean of the Homewood schools,
and Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, director
of student activities, and now
must be mimeographed and distributed to dorm residents. Carleton Jones, DSRC president, expects a general dorm vote on the
constitution on April 27. "The
constitution should be accepted
by May 1," he stated.
Said Gallagher: "I would like to
urge every resident of the dormitory to examine thoroughly the
new constitution and to vote intelligently on it. Personally, I believe the constitution is a good
foundation for governing the dormitory, and that it should be
passed."
It was the consensus of opinion of the DSRC that the most

controversial article of the new
constitution was Article VI, "Enforcement of the Gentleman's
Code."
Members of the trial board and
their primary duties set up under
Article VI are as follows: the
president and vice president alternate as chairman of the board;
the secretary serves as defense
counsel; the treasurer acts as recorder; voting members of the
board are five entry representatives chosen by the president and
vice-president.
Tentative scheduling was made
by the DSRC to hold a vote for
officers on May 10, if the constitution is ratified by May 1. As
soon as the elections are over,
room assignments will be made.
Room assignments must wait until after elections because first
choice of rooms goes to the officers of the DSRC.

Mitgang New Head
Of Booster Club

"Springtime" will be the theme
for the semi-formal DSRC dance
to be held May 5, 9 p.m. to 1 a.m.,
in the snack bar and patio behind
the new dorms, according to Herb
Kahler, Dorm Social Committee
chairman.
"There will be dancing both inside and out; but, because the
floor in the snack bar is more
suited to dancing, all the tables
will be outside," Kahler stated,
adding that Bill Maisel and his
Orchestra will provide music.
Tickets cost $1.50 and may be obtained from any DSRC entry representative.
"We are very pleased to get that
date because it is a pretty good
weekend," stated Kahler. "In the
first place, there are no classes
on Friday, and Saturday has a
full program of sports.

Booster Club elections installed
Bob Mitgang as president, Tony
Salem as vice-president, Larry
Kerpelman as secretary, and Jack
Ruffle as treasurer, it was announced recently.
Mitgang, who served as treasurer during the past year, outlined Booster projects for the present and the future. The Boosters,
according to their new president,
are "looking into possibilities for
re-recording the Glee Club's Hopkins songs," in order to have more
and different songs sung and
-thereby increase spirit." Also in
the works are caravans to "away"
lacrosse games, which Mitgang
terms "a possibility."

Dorm Prom Slated
For May In Patio

Hide and Seek, the 1955 Marburg Prize-winning three-act play
by Aurand Harris, will be produced by the Johns Hopkins Playshop, April 24-28, at 8:30 p.m. in
the Barn, director David Unumb
announced.
The "mood play," stressing a
"character study" more than the
plot, has "many things and ideas
not written into the script that
must be implied through the acting," Unumb added. "The actors
must develop the characters," not
relying on the plot or script to
do this for them. The "set is simple, and there is a great use of
sound and lighting to convey the
character of the different roles,"
Unumb also stated.

The crowning of the winner of
the Ugly Man Contest during the
halftime ceremonies of tomorrow's
Hopkins-Washington and Lee lacrosse game will climax the past
week's World University Service
drive.
Co-chairmen Bill Loring and
Bill Willis are optimistic that the
annual fund-raising campaign,
which ends at 6:00 p.m. today will
reach the expected goal of $800.

MU Gets Loot For Flicks
Twenty-five thousand dollars
been granted to the - Johns
Hopkins University to finance a
series of motion pictures dealing
With great university scholars
and lectures on their specialties,
Dr- Lowell J. Reed, president of
the University,
announced last
Week.
Directed by the University's
director of public relations, Lynn
Poole, the films are designed to
be incorporated into a film library
Of the
world's greatest teachers.
Lectures by outstanding authorities in all
phases of university education, incorporating many visual
aids, will be preserved on film and

haS

presented in classrooms throughout the nation, Poole stated.
The grant was given to the University by the Fund for the Advancement of Education. Hopkins
was one of the 34 schools given
grants, from over 1,100 applicants.
Poole stated that he hopes to
capture in each film a unique contribution to subjects in many
fields by the top scholars available. He said that he will use the
most vivid methods of presenting
scientific material possible, and
that the emphasis in the films will
be placed on subjects of value in
many schools. Work on the series
will start in the near future.

Pershing Riflers
Hold Drill Contest
Drill teams from schools in the
Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania area will compete in an all
day regimental drill meet at
Homewood Field, April 28, under
the sponsorship of the Pershing
Rifles.
Over 20 units from universities
and colleges throughout the area
are expected to participate in
the contest, according to Second
Lieutenant Russ Marcuri. The
meet is an annual event,
Representatives from the United
States Army, Navy, and Air Force
will judge the contest.

Winfield J. Giguere, or Giggs as he is
known, graduated in 1954 from the University of New Hampshire with a B.S.
in Electrical Engineering. Shortly after
graduation he joined Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, New Jersey.
"Experience has come my way in a
hurry," says Giggs. "I've worked on
carrier system amplifiers, speech transmission problems, and experimental
types of coaxial cable. The Labs are always pushing ahead, trying new ideas,
exploring new developments.
"For example, right now I'm working
with 'the transistor that smashed a fre-

quency barrier.' This new transistor has
a cut-off frequency of at least 500 mc and
can be used to amplify 2500 separate
telephone conversations simultaneously.
It will make possible broadband, high.
frequency amplification in many fields
using subminiature components.
"There are thousands of other fascinating projects underway at the Bell Labs.
You see, at the Labs our business is new
ideas, new developments, and that's one
reason why I like working here. It's exciting. If there are better ways to communicate, you can bet the Labs are looking
for them."

Decline And Fall
For the past three years the Cotillion Board has been
notoriously deficient in carrying out even its minimal duties:
the planning of large social functions, the handling of funds,
the coordination of diverse social events, and the holding
of a "try-out" system each year for the selection of new
Board members.
But this year it appears that the Cotillion Board has
reached the nadir of its career; it has at vari6us times fallen
down in every broad field of its stated endeavors. In order,
the Board has shown itself incapable of planning large social
functions by neglecting its own recent dance to the point
where it had not certainly secured a spot for it until three
days before the dance itself; incompetent in the handling
of funds by failing to turn over to the SAC the proceeds from
that dance until threatened with disbandment; inadequate
in the coordination of social events by confusing the dance
dates of the IFB and the "H" Club and by so doing forcing
the IFB spring formal into the dreary confines of the gym;
,and of questionable ability in the handling of try-outs by
electing new members, it is suspected, largely -on the rigid
basis of fraternity alliances.
The SAC, long patient, is finally contemplating the recommendation to the administration that the Cotillion Board
be sweepingly reorganized—that its purposes and the machinery foy accomplishing those purposes be redefined.
We wonder whether the trouble with the Cotillion Board
is not so much a failure in the construct of the organization's machinery as it is the deficiencies of the people who
are running the Board and have been running it for as
• long as we can remember—people who are the product of
the near-complete domination of the Cotillion Board by a
single fraternity.
In this light, we again wonder whether the SAC's threatened reorganization of the machinery is really aimed at the
heart of the Board's annual difficulty, i.e., the personnel. But
we are forced to the conclusion that the only way, in our
democratic community to dispense with the products of
stale machinery is to dispense with the machinery.

Another Kind Of Academic Freedom
There is no greater temptation for an adult than
to admonish or correct an adolescent and even that quasiadolescent, the college man. Especially is it tempting for an
administrator, whose whole raison d'etre is to keep things
running smoothly and noiselessly, to stifle the activities of
always inquisitive, but admittedly inexperienced, collegiate
journalists. The News-Letter's exchange files reveal more
than one_campus paper whose editorial probings have been
throttled, sometimes by an ouster of the editors.
Our recent "sacre du printemps," which, thanks to the
activities of non-News-Letter people, angered the Chairman
of the Board of Trustees, was the crucial test of journalistic
freedom here; the administration passed with flying colors
—no recriminations, no threats, no reprisals.
More to the point are the administrative reactions to
serious columnar content—especially what is found in the
editorial columns. Here the long-term administrator reads,
year after year, things which he would rather keep quiet—
often chronic and virtually insoluble problems, whose rehashing, though of interest to the ever-changing student
body, merely re-opens, for him, a controversy he had hoped
was finally buried.
Yet for five generations of News-Letter editors, no edict
of suppression has ever been laid down as a fiat; treatment
of the touchiest issues has been left to the discretion of the
editors. It seems to us that this policy is of value for two
reasons: it provides a clear, honest atmosphere for the incubation of a thinking man (the journalist himself), and it
recognizes that the services of a gadfly—even as imperfect
a one as the amateur editor—are not without significance.

Beginning Monday
The Veterans' Club is collecting
books, starting Monday, on the
American way of life for distribution to Asian students in an
effort to mollify the influence of
Communist propaganda, project
Chairman Hugh Downs announced
recently.
Books will be collected in the
lobby of Levering Great Hall in
a depository marked for that purpose. Goucher College as well as
many other colleges are doing
similar work, although the Goucher project is under the supervision of the Veterans' Club.

(Continued from Page 1)
News - Letter this enumeration,
saying that the release of any
such list would depend on a further decision of the SAC.
"We Have Improved"
Cotillion Board President Norm
Vander Noot stated, ''The action
of the SAC this week on the Cotillion Board was to a great extent
justified as much as was expected.
It is hard to offer excuses for the
things that have gone wrong, but
I must say that we have improved.
Such an action would not have
taken place if this had been the
first year that the Cotillion Board
has 'malfunctioned,' and on the
basis I would say that action was
unjustified. I stressed at the beginning of the year that we were
in the process of reorganizing and
I regret that the board hasn't
lived up to the expectations that
many held. They have done much
that was good, certainly."
Belgrad stated that SAC had
held high hopes for the Cotillion
Board's potentials for this year, as
long as it was felt there was a
chance they could correct themselves.
Coordination Is Valuable
Vander Noot said that he
thought a Student Council committee to coordinate all scheduling of campus assemblies, athletic
contests, class meetings and social
events would be of value to the
Cotillion Board since it would
"bring to bear pressure on those
groups that will not comply with
our 'deadline for dates' notice."
This, he said, would keep the expediting of failure to co-operate
with these stipulations in the
hands of the representatives of
the class.
Vander Noot said, "I stated to
the SAC earlier this year that we
were in the process of reorganization, and I'm afraid we haven't
lived up to their expectations. Dur-

ing the first part of the year we
were trying to work under a constitution that was definitely not
suited to the work we wanted to
do. We wrote a new constitution,
approved it, and sent it to the
Student Council for final approval,
which was not granted until February. The things in the constitution mainly were pointed at things
to be done in the future, and were
not to be enforced immediately."
Vander Noot summed up the
Cotillion Board's action so far this
year. "Besides our constitution the
Cotillion Board has started on
many projects which were important. First we have collected information on all ball rooms and
bands in town. We have set up a
file by price for both of these
and will bring them up to date
periodically. Secondly, we have
already started work on the social
schedule for all of next year and
are co-sponsoring the BIA calendar for next year and making it
bigger and we hope better. Thirdly,
we are trying to get some sort of
uniformity in the scheduling of
events by planning a permanent
calendar.

Elections for all other undergraduate offices were held last
week, but the balloting for the
office of SC president was voided
by the committee counting the
ballots when it was learned that
the incumbent president, Bob Peinado, had violated one of the rules
established by the Council to govern counting procedure.
The violated rule stated that no
ballots were to be counted prior
to 2 p.m. Thursday, the second day
of voting. Peinado, however,
counted Wednesday night a week
ago the results of the first day's
balloting.
The committee decided that the
violation of the election regulation necessitated the revote on
the grounds that, although it was
"highly probable" that the election was not influenced by the
premature vote - counting, "the
Council can control the moral considerations involved in an election
only by regulations set up previously to govern that election and
by the subsequent upholding of
those regulations." Sanford Cohen,
Herbert Belgrad, Porter Claxton,
Howard Waskow, and Peinado
comprised the committee.

action with "A law of the Council
was broken by my counting the

of the prescribed time. Before
counting the votes I did consider
the ruling of the Council, but I
felt that I was not doing wrong
because I knew that neither I nor

The Dormitory Student Representative Council Constitution is
nearly ready for presentation to
the dorm students, according to
Constitution Chairman Don Gal/agher.
The constitution has been approved by Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer,
dean of the Homewood schools,
and Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, director
of student activities, and now
must be mimeographed and distributed to dorm residents. Carleton Jones, DSRC president, expects a general dorm vote on the
constitution on April 27. "The
constitution should be accepted
by May 1," he stated.
Said Gallagher: "I would like to
urge every resident of the dormitory to examine thoroughly the
new constitution and to vote intelligently on it. Personally, I believe the constitution is a good
foundation for governing the dormitory, and that it should be
passed."
It was the consensus of opinion of the DSRC that the most

controversial article of the new
constitution was Article VI, "Enforcement of the Gentleman's
Code."
Members of the trial board and
their primary duties set up under
Article VI are as follows: the
president and vice president alternate as chairman of the board;
the secretary serves as defense
counsel; the treasurer acts as recorder; voting members of the
board are five entry representatives chosen by the president and
vice-president.
Tentative scheduling was made
by the DSRC to hold a vote for
officers on May 10, if the constitution is ratified by May 1. As
soon as the elections are over,
room assignments will be made.
Room assignments must wait until after elections because first
choice of rooms goes to the officers of the DSRC.

Mitgang New Head
Of Booster Club

"Springtime" will be the theme
for the semi-formal DSRC dance
to be held May 5, 9 p.m. to 1 a.m.,
in the snack bar and patio behind
the new dorms, according to Herb
Kahler, Dorm Social Committee
chairman.
"There will be dancing both inside and out; but, because the
floor in the snack bar is more
suited to dancing, all the tables
will be outside," Kahler stated,
adding that Bill Maisel and his
Orchestra will provide music.
Tickets cost $1.50 and may be obtained from any DSRC entry representative.
"We are very pleased to get that
date because it is a pretty good
weekend," stated Kahler. "In the
first place, there are no classes
on Friday, and Saturday has a
full program of sports.

Booster Club elections installed
Bob Mitgang as president, Tony
Salem as vice-president, Larry
Kerpelman as secretary, and Jack
Ruffle as treasurer, it was announced recently.
Mitgang, who served as treasurer during the past year, outlined Booster projects for the present and the future. The Boosters,
according to their new president,
are "looking into possibilities for
re-recording the Glee Club's Hopkins songs," in order to have more
and different songs sung and
-thereby increase spirit." Also in
the works are caravans to "away"
lacrosse games, which Mitgang
terms "a possibility."

Dorm Prom Slated
For May In Patio

Hide and Seek, the 1955 Marburg Prize-winning three-act play
by Aurand Harris, will be produced by the Johns Hopkins Playshop, April 24-28, at 8:30 p.m. in
the Barn, director David Unumb
announced.
The "mood play," stressing a
"character study" more than the
plot, has "many things and ideas
not written into the script that
must be implied through the acting," Unumb added. "The actors
must develop the characters," not
relying on the plot or script to
do this for them. The "set is simple, and there is a great use of
sound and lighting to convey the
character of the different roles,"
Unumb also stated.

the Ugly Man Contest during the
halftime ceremonies of tomorrow's
Hopkins-Washington and Lee lacrosse game will climax the past
week's World University Service
drive.
Co-chairmen Bill Loring and
Bill Willis are optimistic that the
annual fund-raising campaign,
which ends at 6:00 p.m. today will
reach the expected goal of $800.

Winfield J. Giguere, or Giggs as he is
known, graduated in 1954 from the University of New Hampshire with a B.S.
in Electrical Engineering. Shortly after
graduation he joined Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, New Jersey.
"Experience has come my way in a
hurry," says Giggs. "I've worked on
carrier system amplifiers, speech transmission problems, and experimental
types of coaxial cable. The Labs are always pushing ahead, trying new ideas,
exploring new developments.
"For example, right now I'm working
with 'the transistor that smashed a fre-

quency barrier.' This new transistor has
a cut-off frequency of at least 500 mc and
can be used to amplify 2500 separate
telephone conversations simultaneously.
It will make possible broadband, high.
frequency amplification in many fields
using subminiature components.
"There are thousands of other fascinating projects underway at the Bell Labs.
You see, at the Labs our business is new
ideas, new developments, and that's one
reason why I like working here. It's exciting. If there are better ways to communicate, you can bet the Labs are looking
for them."

Dr. Oppenheimer Emphasizes
Philosophic,NotTechnic, uest

Decline And Fall
For the past three years the Cotillion Board has been
notoriously deficient in carrying out even its minimal duties:
the planning of large social functions, the handling of funds,
the coordination of diverse social events, and the holding
of a "try-out" system each year for the selection of new
Board members.
But this year it appears that the Cotillion Board has
reached the nadir of its career; it has at vari6us times fallen
down in every broad field of its stated endeavors. In order,
the Board has shown itself incapable of planning large social
functions by neglecting its own recent dance to the point
where it had not certainly secured a spot for it until three
days before the dance itself; incompetent in the handling
of funds by failing to turn over to the SAC the proceeds from
that dance until threatened with disbandment; inadequate
in the coordination of social events by confusing the dance
dates of the IFB and the "H" Club and by so doing forcing
the IFB spring formal into the dreary confines of the gym;
,and of questionable ability in the handling of try-outs by
electing new members, it is suspected, largely -on the rigid
basis of fraternity alliances.
The SAC, long patient, is finally contemplating the recommendation to the administration that the Cotillion Board
be sweepingly reorganized—that its purposes and the machinery foy accomplishing those purposes be redefined.
We wonder whether the trouble with the Cotillion Board
is not so much a failure in the construct of the organization's machinery as it is the deficiencies of the people who
are running the Board and have been running it for as
• long as we can remember—people who are the product of
the near-complete domination of the Cotillion Board by a
single fraternity.
In this light, we again wonder whether the SAC's threatened reorganization of the machinery is really aimed at the
heart of the Board's annual difficulty, i.e., the personnel. But
we are forced to the conclusion that the only way, in our
democratic community to dispense with the products of
stale machinery is to dispense with the machinery.

Another Kind Of Academic Freedom
There is no greater temptation for an adult than
to admonish or correct an adolescent and even that quasiadolescent, the college man. Especially is it tempting for an
administrator, whose whole raison d'etre is to keep things
running smoothly and noiselessly, to stifle the activities of
always inquisitive, but admittedly inexperienced, collegiate
journalists. The News-Letter's exchange files reveal more
than one_campus paper whose editorial probings have been
throttled, sometimes by an ouster of the editors.
Our recent "sacre du printemps," which, thanks to the
activities of non-News-Letter people, angered the Chairman
of the Board of Trustees, was the crucial test of journalistic
freedom here; the administration passed with flying colors
—no recriminations, no threats, no reprisals.
More to the point are the administrative reactions to
serious columnar content—especially what is found in the
editorial columns. Here the long-term administrator reads,
year after year, things which he would rather keep quiet—
often chronic and virtually insoluble problems, whose rehashing, though of interest to the ever-changing student
body, merely re-opens, for him, a controversy he had hoped
was finally buried.
Yet for five generations of News-Letter editors, no edict
of suppression has ever been laid down as a fiat; treatment
of the touchiest issues has been left to the discretion of the
editors. It seems to us that this policy is of value for two
reasons: it provides a clear, honest atmosphere for the incubation of a thinking man (the journalist himself), and it
recognizes that the services of a gadfly—even as imperfect
a one as the amateur editor—are not without significance.

many other colleges are doing
similar work, although the Goucher project is under the supervision of the Veterans' Club.

"We Have Improved"
Cotillion Board President Norm
Vander Noot stated, ''The action
of the SAC this week on the Cotillion Board was to a great extent
justified as much as was expected.
It is hard to offer excuses for the
things that have gone wrong, but
I must say that we have improved.
Such an action would not have
taken place if this had been the
first year that the Cotillion Board
has 'malfunctioned,' and on the
basis I would say that action was
unjustified. I stressed at the beginning of the year that we were
in the process of reorganizing and
I regret that the board hasn't
lived up to the expectations that
many held. They have done much
that was good, certainly."
Belgrad stated that SAC had
held high hopes for the Cotillion
Board's potentials for this year, as
long as it was felt there was a
chance they could correct themselves.
Coordination Is Valuable
Vander Noot said that he
thought a Student Council committee to coordinate all scheduling of campus assemblies, athletic
contests, class meetings and social
events would be of value to the
Cotillion Board since it would
"bring to bear pressure on those
groups that will not comply with
our 'deadline for dates' notice."
This, he said, would keep the expediting of failure to co-operate
with these stipulations in the
hands of the representatives of
the class.
Vander Noot said, "I stated to
the SAC earlier this year that we
were in the process of reorganization, and I'm afraid we haven't
lived up to their expectations. Dur-

ing the first part of the year we
were trying to work under a constitution that was definitely not
suited to the work we wanted to
do. We wrote a new constitution,
approved it, and sent it to the
Student Council for final approval,
which was not granted until February. The things in the constitution mainly were pointed at things
to be done in the future, and were
not to be enforced immediately."
Vander Noot summed up the
Cotillion Board's action so far this
year. "Besides our constitution the
Cotillion Board has started on
many projects which were important. First we have collected information on all ball rooms and
bands in town. We have set up a
file by price for both of these
and will bring them up to date
periodically. Secondly, we have
already started work on the social
schedule for all of next year and
are co-sponsoring the BIA calendar for next year and making it
bigger and we hope better. Thirdly,
we are trying to get some sort of
uniformity in the scheduling of
events by planning a permanent
calendar.

"Two Soldiers", a pair of first
novels under one cover by a Hopkins graduate of 1949, Paxton
Davis, will be published by Simon
and Schuster May 10, the publishing house announced this week.
Davis, who entered Hopkins in
the fall of 1946 as an English major, after serving as a medical sergeant in the China-Burma-India
Theater—the scene of the two
novels—is currently an Assistant
Professor of Journalism at Washington and Lee University. Prior
to going to Washington and Lee,
he was a reporter on newspapers
in Winston-Salem, North Carolina,
Richmond, Virginia, and the Twin
Cities.
